comment.author: 28996044@N00
comment._content: Perhaps somewhere near the Baltic coast, judging by the stepped gable facades typical of North Germany?

comment.author: 34419668@N08
comment._content:
Try pod, you sure have a point there! Stepped gables are common in several countries in northern Europe as well as around the Baltic sea - in Germany, the Netherlands, Denmark and Sweden, to mention some where Carl Curman travelled.

I reckon this could indeed be a useful clue in identifying the location of the photo :)
/Anna B.

comment.author: 34880063@N06
comment._content: Hello, let us suggest it is a church... so the roof of the church is maybe a protestant one... (small on top of wide) see here: de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liste_der_Kirchen_der_Evangelisch-r... There are several in northern Germany... it is sad but wiki has not all pictures of the listet churches :( but i think it is one of the big city churches. BUT: in WW2 most of the roofs were destroyed, several buildings were restored with smaller roofs after.

comment.author: 38522966@N06
comment._content: What's about Gdańsk (Danzig). Roads that are as long as this one will only be found in bigger cities in the 1880s. There were three towers in Gdańsk at the end of a long road. 1) The tower could belong to the city hall at the end of the "Langer Markt" (Długi Targ/ Long Market): pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/D%c5%82ugi_Targ The Long Market is famous for houses with stepped gables. 2) It could be the train station tower: www.antik-falkensee.de/catalog/product_info.php?products_... www.antik-falkensee.de/catalog/product_info.php?products_... 3) But the silhouette seems to fit best with the prison tower (Stockturm) The postcards are from the 1920s. In the 1880s might not have been so many high buildings and your photo was taken far from the tower away...

comment.author: 34880063@N06
comment._content: Or this here: www.antik-falkensee.de/catalog/popup_image.php?pID=135605... Elbing Westpreussen Alter Markt ca 1940 Or this: www.antik-falkensee.de/catalog/popup_image.php?pID=132675... Danzig Hohes Tor.

comment.author: 34880063@N06
comment._content:
Ich denke es ist Rostock. Neuer Markt, mit Blick durch die Kröpliner Straße. Die Baugrundstücke zur Rechten sind in ihrer Reihenfolge lang lang kurz kurz kurz lang. Das ist heute noch so wenn man von Oben auf google-maps schaut.

Jag tycker att det är Rostock. New Market, med utsikt över gatan Kroeplin. Det tomtmark på höger, i ordning av lång lång kort kort kort lång. Den dagen är fortfarande så om du tittar längst upp på Google-kartor.

comment.author: 38522966@N06
comment._content: Maybe the image helps a little to identify this landmark: Unfortunately you cannot see a lot of shadows on the photo. But the shadows of the people in front are small and it could be around noon. That means the tower must be to the SE/E of the photographer.

comment.author: 8479414@N04
comment._content:
ich glaube, durch aperture7.1 negative ist deutlich zu sehen, dass das turmdach einem satteldach gleicht. die beiden giebelwände sind an den gräten(rändern) stufig nach oben geführt. der aufgesetzte glockenturm ist ebenfalls zweistufig mit kuppeldachabschluss(turmknopf). zu oberst sitzt eine einfache windrose mit (ich vermute es) ost - west ausrichtung und darüber eine wetterfahne



Jag tror, är genom negativ aperture7.1 kan tydligt se att tornet taket är som en sadel. är de två gavel väggarna i fiskbensmönstrad (kanterna) skede ledde till toppen. Plåstret är också två nivåer klocktorn med uttalanden kupol tak (torn knappen). Tillbaka till början sitter en enkel Windrose med (jag misstänker det) öst - västlig riktning och över en vindflöjel

comment.author: 27644288@N02
comment._content: @ Newchurch Ich würde sagen, es handelt sich hierbei zu 100% nicht um eine Aufnahme aus Rostock. Die Kröpeliner Strasse sieht heute noch immer der von damals sehr ähnlich, auch wenn hier und dar eine andere Bebauung vorherscht, so ist der Strassenverlauf doch gleich geblieben und dieser ähnelt in keinster Weise dem der Abbildung. Zudem war die Strassenbreite sehr viel geringer als hier abgebildet. Ebenso haben sehr viele Gebäude der Kröpeliner Strasse (ehemals Blutstrasse) die Bombardements der Allierten überstanden, welches eine Ausnahme bildet, da viele Straßenzüge Rostock's zerstört wurden, so dass auch heute noch viele Gebäude aus damaliger Zeit stehen, wenn auch restauriert. Zudem handelt es sich hierbei auf der Abblidung um untypische Bauten, zu damaliger Zeit waren und sind auch heute noch Giebelhäuser in der Kröpeliner Strasse zu bewundern, wie z.B.: www.mv-terra-incognita.de/beitraege/denkmale/k/237.htm www.mv-terra-incognita.de/gesamt.htm?files/links.htm~main...

comment.author: 10133503@N03
comment._content: Well, the church roof certainly looks like the Marktkirche in Hannover but I think the street is far too spacious to show any street near the Marktkirche around that time...

comment.author: 8479414@N04
34419668@N08
comment._content:
Great to read all your comments, and I follow your discussion with excitement! I suppose the church would be another key to the identification as well. It's so intriguing, and i keep my finger crossed for a solution!

aperture 7.1: Suppose Carl Curman went from Sweden to Germany by boat, I don't think Danzig would be the port town he passed by - it would be a large detour.

fredifroeschki: The photo is not a high resolution scan, and the scan is made from a copy, not from a negative. We have examined the photo in full scan though; the church is not more visible than in the image by aperture 7.1. A sign on the coach door is not readable. The left sign on the street corner has a word on top that ends with a "g" (could be "König" but we're not sure about that) but it's hardly readable.

/Anna B.

comment.author: 42058931@N06
comment._content:
Just as the other picture, we are discussing this issue on the german wikipedia (http://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Auskunft#Wer_kennt_diese_Stadt.3F)

As Anna has pointed out and as I have said there, Danzig probably would  have been a detour: curman lived in Stockholm, where he was a professor. The Heritage Board has pictures from Germany taken by Curman from 1880 till 1882.

My theory so far: curman went on holiday (or something similar, e.g. treatment at a helath resort) to Germany, where he took photos of the Brocken, south of Hannover. The next pictures are from Stuttgart and Heidelberg (1881) in south western Germany and from the Black Forest in the same area. We then have again pictures from Goslar near the Brocken (1882) and Sylt, an island near Denmark. 

So I suppose he travelled via Malmö to Germany, the Black Forest and the same route back again, spending notable time in spas in south western Germany and around the Brocken, taking lots of nature photos. On his way back, he visited Sylt, where we have again quite a few photos. In 1883, there are only photos from Denmark and Sweden. Others on Wikipedia sugessted, he could have visited eastern Prussia by train, but I don't think so, regarding the infrastructure and the enorme detour.

PS: The black bars at the left marging could either be due to Curman's camera, or he took the shoot out of a carriage. Also, take a look at the scenery: compare the distance to this supposedly important building with the few people on the street. One said, this relation could apply to hannover or rostock at that time, but not to smaller cities.

Update: He supposedly didn't go on holiday, since he was intendent of Lysekil's seaside spa. There are also spas in Bad Harzburg, Sylt and the Black Forest, where he took several pictures.

comment.author: 29549513@N08
comment._content:
Is it sure that this picture is taken in Gerrmany? Broadness of the street indicates a bigger city - even the distance to the either church or town gate.
It's really flat - there aren't to many bigger cities in the northern part of either Germany or Poland with any building shaped like the one in the background. My first thought it could be some part of Berlin, but the gas lanterns look different.
So I wowouldhink it could be a city in France... I had seen more roofs with a similar shape there than in some other areas.

comment.author: 44217659@N08
comment._content: The search has an end. It is the Königsstraße in Hannover, Germany. The building in the distance is indeed a church, the Marktkirche. For more information an pictures look at www.skyscrapercity.com/showthread.php?t=572039&page=8 Greets Tobi
